questions.question_text: How do you configure Spanning-tree EtherChannel guard?

discussion.content: You can enable this feature by using the spanning-tree etherchannel guard misconfig global configuration command.
If the switch detects a misconfiguration on the other device, EtherChannel guard places the switch interfaces in the error-disabled state, and displays an error message.

questions.question_text: If EtherChannel guard is configured, how the interface status is (or looks like) if misconfigured?

discussion.content: A 16-bit field set to a value of 0x8100 in order to identify the frame as an IEEE 802.1Q-tagged frame.

questions.question_text: Which option is the TPI 802.1Q tag?
questions.answer_description: 16-bit field set to 0x8100 in order to identify the frame as 802.1q tagged frame.

discussion.content:
Switch#sh int fa 0/1 switchport 
Name: Fa0/1
Switchport: Enabled
Administrative Mode: dynamic auto
Operational Mode: static access
Administrative Trunking Encapsulation: 
Operational Trunking Encapsulation: native
Negotiation of Trunking: On
Access Mode VLAN: 1 (default)

Yes, C

"A dynamic (nontrunking) port can belong to only one VLAN. When the link comes up, the switch does not forward traffic to or from this port until the port is assigned to a VLAN. The source MAC address from the first packet of a new host on the dynamic port is sent to the VMPS, which attempts to match the MAC address to a VLAN in the VMPS database. If there is a match, the VMPS sends the VLAN number for that port. If there is no match, the VMPS either denies the request or shuts down the port (depending on the VMPS secure mode setting)."

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst4500/12-2/20ew/configuration/guide/config/vmps.html
check output from my switch - the correct answer is C. Port gi0/8 which is set as dynamic access is not assigned to vlan1.

No. A - is right. 
By default all unassigned ports of the switch are members of the default VLAN 1.

discussion.content: I think C. none until the port VLAN is determined is correct

questions.question_text: A dynamic access port is member of which VLAN by default?

choices.C: none until the port VLAN is determined

questions.question_text: What will be behavior of an access port when a tagged packet is received with a VLAN ID of an access port?

discussion.content: If an access port receives a packet with an 802.1Q tag in the header other than the access VLAN value, that port drops the packet without learning its MAC source address.

An access port belongs to and carries the traffic of only one VLAN (unless it is configured as a voice VLAN port). Traffic is received and sent in native formats with no VLAN tagging.Traffic arriving on access port is assumed to belong to the VLAN assigned to the port. If access port receives a tagged packet (Inter-Switch Link (ISL) or IEEE802.1Q tagged), the packet is dropped, and the source address is not learned

Hi,
Access port received the end device than it will add 802.1q & if it receive with tag already for same Vlan than simply remove the Tag and forward the frame.

Hi,

if it's tagged for a VLAN to which the interface is assigned to, it should accept it.

In other cases it should drop it.

HTH,

Milan

choices.D: tag is removed and packet is forwarded on the VLAN of the access port
choices.B: tag is removed and packet is forwarded to the VLAN mentioned in the tag
